channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis Updates: Israel Launches Intense Airstrikes on Hezbollah, Killing Hundreds in Lebanon
item.description: It was the deadliest day of Israeli attacks in Lebanon since at least 2006. More than a thousand were also injured, Lebanon’s health ministry said, without saying how many were civilians. The armed group Hezbollah sent rockets into northern Israel and vowed to keep attacking.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times

item.title: Forced From Home by War, They Found Solace in Soccer
item.description: For dozens of women who fled Myanmar and settled in Thailand, soccer has become a refuge from both the troubles of daily life and conservative cultural norms.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrating proper ball handling technique during a practice session for an all-women soccer team in Mae Sot, Thailand.

item.title: As U.N. Meets, Pressure Mounts on Biden to Loosen Up on Arms for Ukraine
item.description: Finland’s president and NATO’s departing secretary general are urging Mr. Biden to allow Ukraine to use weapons to hit bases deeper inside Russia.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Biden with President Alexander Stubb of Finland, center, and Jens Stoltenberg of NATO in July. The two favor letting Ukraine use longer-range weapons against Russia.

item.title: U.N. Meets Amid a Backdrop of Growing Chaos and Violence
item.description: Beginning Tuesday, world leaders will discuss three wars, climate change, rising sea levels and proposals to expand representation on the Security Council.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The United Nations headquarters in New York. By most accounts, the world has descended even deeper into chaos and violence since last year’s meeting of the General Assembly.

item.title: U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer, Bruised by Freebies Row, Needs a Reset at Conference
item.description: The Labour Party’s annual conference should have been a jubilant occasion. But Keir Starmer is on the defensive after intense scrutiny of gifts that he and his wife accepted.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, center, with Rachel Reeves, the chancellor of the Exchequer, left, and deputy prime minister Angela Rayner, at the Labour Party’s annual conference in Liverpool, England, on Sunday.

item.title: Tanzania Arrests Opposition Leaders Ahead of Planned Protest
item.description: The East African country’s leading opposition party said that its presidential candidate in the last election and its chairman were among dozens detained before a protest called to draw attention to the killing and abduction of government critics.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:description: Freeman Mbowe, chairman of Tanzania’s main opposition party, Chadema, being detained by the police in Dar es Salaam on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Needs to Be Realistic About Goals in War With Russia, Czech President Says
item.description: President Petr Pavel, a former NATO general who has been vocal in his support for Ukraine, said Kyiv needed to accept that some territory could remain under Russian control, at least “temporarily.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Petr Pavel of the Czech Republic at a NATO summit in Washington in July.

item.title: Russian Military Plane Breaches Japan’s Airspace
item.description: The infringements were the first by Russia in five years, according to the Japanese defense ministry. A fighter fired a warning flare in response.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Russian plane reportedly flew above Rebun Island, northwest of Hokkaido, Japan’s northernmost prefecture.

item.title: A French Fair as Workers’ Paradise, Feting Cuisine, Music and Communism
item.description: The Fête de l’Humanité, a blend of Burning Man, Woodstock and a political convention, attracts the masses with bands, lectures and food, but here K.F.C. is C.F.K.: Communist Fried Kitchen.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fête de l’Humanité, a popular festival on the outskirts of Paris, celebrates left-wing politics in general, and French Communism in particular.

item.title: Supermarkets in Australia Sued Over Claims of Fake Discounts
item.description: In a rare case of legal action tied to rising prices, the government sued Woolworths and Coles for what it described as a pattern of deceiving consumers.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: AnnaMaria Antoinette D'Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coles and Woolworths control 65 percent of the grocery store market in Australia.

item.title: Pope Francis Cancels Meetings, Citing Flu With More Travel Looming
item.description: Francis, 87, is scheduled to visit Belgium and Luxembourg soon, trips that come within weeks of his returning from a grueling Asia-Pacific tour.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Pope Francis leading prayer from his office overlooking St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City on Sunday.

item.title: For Israel, Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Take a Back Seat to Military Force
item.description: After years of failed deals and tit-for-tat violence, neither the Israelis nor the Palestinians believe their adversaries will ever negotiate in good faith.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: The site of an Israeli airstrike in the southern Lebanese village of Khiam on Thursday. Recent attacks have fueled concerns of a broader regional war.

item.title: In Germany, Scholz’s Party Ekes Out Win Over Far Right
item.description: The narrow win by Olaf Scholz’s party came in a state election, the third in a series that was seen as a reflection of the national mood and a snapshot of the government’s popularity.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Dietmar Woidke, center, the Social Democrat governor of the state of Brandenburg, in Potsdam, Germany, on Sunday.

item.title: Sri Lanka Elects Leftist Leader Dissanayake as President
item.description: Anura Kumara Dissanayake’s strong showing reveals voter weariness with leadership that has led to a national economic crisis and crushing hardship for many people.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Pamodi Waravita
item.category: Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (Sri Lankan Political Party)
item.media:description: Anura Kumara Dissanayake, center, leaving a polling station after casting his vote in the presidential election in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Saturday.

item.title: Earthquake Off Japan Coast Triggers Tsunami Advisory
item.description: The earthquake occurred off the coast of Torishima Island, which is uninhabited, at 8:14 a.m. on Tuesday, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency. The advisory was lifted at 11 a.m.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: The Japan Meteorological Agency issued tsunami advisories for the Izu and Ogasawara islands off the coast of Japan after an earthquake on Tuesday.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds as Warplanes Target Hezbollah
item.description: It was the deadliest day in decades of hostilities between Israel and the militants, who stepped up their own barrage of rockets.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Southern Lebanon hit by Israeli strikes on Monday.

item.title: Russia’s Next-Generation Nuclear Missile Failed a Test, Evidence Suggests
item.description: Satellite photos showing a 200-foot-wide crater at a launch site indicate that the Sarmat missile, said by the Kremlin to travel at five times the speed of sound, might not be ready for duty.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A satellite image taken on Saturday showing a Sarmat missile launch site that was apparently damaged in an explosion during a test launch.

item.title: Biden Works Against the Clock as Violence Escalates in the Middle East
item.description: President Biden is beginning to acknowledge that he is simply running out of time to help forge a cease-fire and hostage deal with Hamas, his aides say. And the risk of a wider war has never looked greater.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: For a year now, President Biden has warned publicly and privately about the need to avoid a broader war in the Middle East, one that could easily escalate into direct conflict between Israel and Iran.

item.title: At U.N. General Assembly, Global Crises Collide With Fraught U.S. Politics
item.description: President Biden will speak at a time of deep uncertainty about the future of America’s role in the world.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivering remarks at the U.N. General Assembly last year. He will meet with President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris this week.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Airstrikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds
item.description: Plus, vintage soccer jerseys and the memories they preserve.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Tyre, southern Lebanon, after Israeli airstrikes on Monday.

item.title: Pakistan Appoints New Head of Its Powerful Spy Agency
item.description: The appointment of a top general, Lt. Gen. Muhammad Asim Malik, to the post comes as the country faces numerous internal and external challenges.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood

item.title: U.S. to Send More Troops to Middle East as Tensions Rise
item.description: Maj. Gen. Patrick S. Ryder, the Pentagon press secretary, declined to say exactly how many troops were deploying, citing operational security.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Israel has carried out a series of attacks on Hezbollah targets in recent days, raising concern in the Biden administration that retaliatory strikes by the group or Iran could endanger U.S. troops in the region.

item.title: Israel Targets Top Hezbollah Commander Ali Karaki in Beirut Strike
item.description: Hezbollah said in a statement that the chief of its forces in southern Lebanon was alive and well.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Mohamad Al Ghandour/AFPTV, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A screen grab from a video showing smoke over the southern suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon, after a strike on Monday.

item.title: A South Korean Olympian Gets to Play an Assassin, but Some Before Her Have Flopped
item.description: Olympians who tried the movies, especially in the 1980s, often fared poorly.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Now that’s a movie star, right?

item.title: Biden Meets With UAE President, Mohammed bin Zayed, in Washington
item.description: The meetings with Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed were expected to focus on Gaza, the war in Sudan and artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ismaeel Naar
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed is the first Emirati president to visit American soil since the United Arab Emirates was founded in 1971.

item.title: Israel Launches Deadly Strikes Across Gaza, Local Officials Say
item.description: The latest in a series of strikes on schools being used as shelters killed three in Nuseirat, according to the Palestinian Civil Defense. Israel has said the buildings were being used by Hamas militants as a command center.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Palestinians at Al-Aqsa Hospital in the central Gaza Strip mourning the death of relatives killed by strikes in Deir Al Balah on Monday.

item.title: Was It Really a Hot Zone Summer?
item.description: From Covid to dengue, viral outbreaks seemed to be popping up all over. But maybe Americans are just more attuned to threats now.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Mosquitoes sickened some Americans with infections like dengue, malaria, West Nile virus and Eastern equine encephalitis. But apart from dengue, the outbreaks were not particularly bad.

item.title: Man Smashes Ai Weiwei’s Porcelain Sculpture at Italian Museum
item.description: The man behind the episode, at a reception for Mr. Ai’s new exhibition in Bologna, has targeted artists before, a museum spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Genus Bononiae Press Office, via Reuters
item.media:description: “Porcelain Cube,” a piece by Ai Weiwei, was smashed to pieces at the Palazzo Fava on Friday.

item.title: Israel-Hezbollah Tensions Spiral in Week of Attacks: What to Know
item.description: Exploding pagers, a major Israeli strike in Beirut and Hezbollah attacks deep inside Israel have brought the two sides closer than they’ve been in years to a full-scale war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral in Beirut on Wednesday for people killed by the exploding devices.

item.title: Fear Spreads in Beirut as Israel Steps Up Strikes
item.description: Lebanon’s Education Ministry ordered some schools to close amid warnings from Israel that it was intensifying strikes against Hezbollah and calls for residents to evacuate.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: Students leaving after some schools closed early in Beirut on Monday.

item.title: Why Israel Is Escalating Attacks Against Hezbollah in Lebanon: News Analysis
item.description: Israel’s intensifying strikes show how determined it is to stop Hezbollah’s cross-border attacks — and how far it is from achieving that goal.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene in Beirut, Lebanon, on Saturday, a day after an Israeli airstrike.

item.title: The World Is a Mess. That Makes the Climate Crisis Harder to Solve.
item.description: A transformed China, conflicts in Ukraine and elsewhere, and intractable clashes over money have pushed the prospects of progress to a new low.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The United Nations headquarters in Manhattan, where the General Assembly begins on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Research Aided Chinese Military Technology, House Republicans Say
item.description: A congressional report argues that Beijing has exploited ties with American universities to advance technologically, and that further guardrails are needed.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.category: House Committee on Education and Labor
item.media:description: Republican members of two House committees recommended curtailing the ability of researchers who receive U.S. grants to work with Chinese universities and companies that have military ties.

item.title: Tourism and Water Shortages on the Greek Islands: A Delicate Balance
item.description: As climate change brings water shortages to vacation hot spots, we look at Greece’s tourism-dependent islands, where residents sometimes compete with visitors for a dwindling supply.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeğinsu and Iliana Magra
item.media:description: Tourism is booming in Sifnos, a small island in the Greek Cyclades, and water supplies are, at times, dwindling. The island is one of several places in Greece that are feeling the pressures of water shortages.

item.title: As Soccer Jerseys Become Vintage Streetwear, Big Investors Buy In
item.description: Vintage soccer jerseys have become a streetwear staple, and a target of major investors. Their real appeal lies in the memories they conjure.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Jack Roe
item.media:description: Doug Bierton’s company, Classic Football Shirts, owns about a million soccer jerseys at any given time.

item.title: 6 Dead in Japan After Record Rainfall Causes Flooding
item.description: The downpour drenched the Noto Peninsula on Saturday, triggering landslides and washing away people and homes, Japan’s national broadcaster said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Miharu Nishiyama
item.media:description: Rescue personnel searching for missing people in Wajima city, Japan, on Monday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Threats
item.description: Plus, a Russian military officer’s story of desertion and escape.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Damage from an early morning strike in Kiryat Bialik, Israel, yesterday.

item.title: Israel and Hezbollah Threaten to Hit Harder, Raising Fears of All-Out War
item.description: A leader of the Iranian-backed militia said its latest barrage was “just the beginning,” and an Israeli military official said, “Our strikes will intensify.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward, Hwaida Saad and Ken Belson
item.media:description: Kiryat Bialik, a town north of Haifa in Israel, after a Hezbollah strike on Sunday.

item.title: Northern Israel Braces for More Attacks From Hezbollah
item.description: Residents of Kiryat Bialik, a community near Haifa, were feeling vulnerable as the back-and-forth attacks escalated recently between Hezbollah and the Israeli military.
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: Buildings and vehicles were damaged in the early morning strike on a residential neighborhood in Kiryat Bialik, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: In a Hezbollah-Dominated Area of Beirut, a Mix of Defiance and Unease
item.description: Many residents of Dahiya were grappling with uncertainty over what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral procession for two Hezbollah commanders moving through Beirut on Sunday.

item.title: Takeaways From ‘The Deserter’ in The New York Times Magazine
item.description: Here is what we can learn about the Russian military and its soldiers from the story of ‘Ivan’ and ‘Anna’ in The New York Times Magazine.
item.dc:creator: Sarah A. Topol
item.media:credit: Elinor Carucci for The New York Times

item.title: Videos From Kiryat Bialik Show Hezbollah Missile Striking Residential Area
item.description: An overnight barrage included around 150 rockets, cruise missiles and drones, Israel’s military said. Air defenses intercepted most, but the town of Kiryat Bialik suffered a direct hit.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese and Malachy Browne
item.media:description: A dashcam video captures the moment a missile fired by Hezbollah struck near Haifa in Israel.

item.title: Congo Releases More Than 700 Inmates After a Deadly Stampede
item.description: At least 129 people died when inmates tried to escape from Makala Prison, where conditions are abysmal and overcrowding is a major problem.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Inmates waiting to be released from Makala Prison in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, on Saturday.

item.title: Explosion at an Iranian Mine Kills Dozens, State Media Says
item.description: A methane leak set off the explosion, the country’s official media said, and a rescue effort was underway for those believed to be trapped in the mine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: At a Remote Scottish Pub, a Pint Worth Hiking 20 Miles
item.description: The Old Forge on the rugged peninsula of Knoydart is a community-owned meeting point for locals and visitors — at least those willing to trek across the wilderness.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The Old Forge is known as the remotest pub in mainland Britain.

item.title: Israel’s Military Closes Al Jazeera’s Office in the West Bank
item.description: The Israeli authorities have been putting pressure on the local operations of the network, saying its coverage threatens national security.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle outside the building that houses the Al Jazeera office in Ramallah, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, on Sunday.

item.title: 1 Dead, Several Missing in Japan After Flooding and Landslides
item.description: One person is dead and seven others are missing in Noto Peninsula, Japanese news media reported. The region is still recovering from a catastrophic earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Residents survey damage after flooding due to heavy rains in Suzu, Ishikawa prefecture, on Saturday.

item.title: Brandenburg State Elections: What to Watch For
item.description: The far right and far left are poised to make significant gains in state voting on Sunday, possibly affecting the stability of the national government in Berlin.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Dietmar Woidke, the governor of the eastern German state of Brandenburg, is one of the most popular members of Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s party, but they have been facing headwinds.

item.title: For Americans Haunted by Beirut Bombings, a Killing Resurfaces Decades of Pain
item.description: The death of a Hezbollah leader wanted for his role in the 1983 attacks drew a range of reactions from survivors and victims’ families but brought little resolution.
item.dc:creator: Kate Selig
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The attack on the U.S. Marine barracks in Beirut, Lebanon, killed more than 300 people, mostly service members.

item.title: Israeli Attacks in Lebanon Mark a Sharp Strategic Shift
item.description: The events of this week seem to indicate that Israel’s leaders have decided they can no longer live with the threat of Hezbollah on their northern border, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Hwaida Saad, Ben Hubbard and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Saturday at the site of an Israeli airstrike in Beirut, Lebanon. Hezbollah has been left in deep disarray by attacks in the past week.

item.title: A Week of Chaos Pushes Lebanon’s Doctors to the Limit
item.description: Exploding wireless devices maimed thousands. An Israeli airstrike on Friday flattened two buildings. Many doctors, exhausted, wonder how the country will cope if violence continues.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: “I am hoping that it was all just a bad dream,” Dr. Dania El-Hallak said.

item.title: Leader of Kenya, Donor to Haiti Police Force, Makes First Visit
item.description: The trip by President William Ruto of Kenya came against a bleak backdrop in Haiti, where gangs operate with impunity and the Kenyan officers remain largely out of sight.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President William Ruto of Kenya, center, with police officers from his country in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Saturday.

item.title: Macron Appoints Cabinet as He Seeks to Move France Out of Political Impasse
item.description: The government still faces two challenges in the coming weeks: the risk of a no-confidence vote and a tight budget deadline.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France hopes to move the country past a several-month-long political impasse.

item.title: U.S. Soldier Pleads Guilty to Desertion After Fleeing Into North Korea
item.description: Pvt. Travis King on Friday pleaded guilty before a military judge to desertion, among other charges, after he made an unauthorized crossing into North Korea in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. Army Pvt. Travis King shown during a news broadcast in Seoul in 2023.

item.title: Israeli Strike on Former School Kills 22, Gazan Health Officials Say
item.description: Gaza’s ministry of health said most of those killed in the strike on the Zeitoun School in Gaza City were women and children.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Gaza’s rescue services said the Saturday strike on Gaza’s Zeitoun School killed mostly women and children.

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Backs Down in Brazil
item.description: In an abrupt reversal, the social network’s lawyers said it was complying with court orders that it had previously defied. Brazil’s Supreme Court could allow the site to return next week.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazil’s Supreme Court blocked X last month because its owner, Elon Musk, refused to comply with court orders.

item.title: Who Was Ahmed Wahbi, One of the Hezbollah Commanders Killed by an Israeli Airstrike?
item.description: The senior Hezbollah leader trained the group’s elite fighting unit and led its support for Hamas after the Oct. 7 attacks, the Lebanese militia said.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Fighters wearing the insignia of the Hezbollah’s Radwan force during a training exercise in southern Lebanon in May 2023.

item.title: For Families of Those Missing After Israeli Strike in Beirut, an Agonizing Wait
item.description: With the death toll rising and rescuers still searching for people beneath the rubble, families were keeping a desperate watch over the site of an Israeli strike in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Saturday at a suburban Beirut residential building that was destroyed in an Israeli airstrike a day earlier.
